note.p: William A. Barbour was a businessman, a Confederate soldier, and a private secretary to Mississippi’s governor during the Civil War.

Little is known of Barbour’s background before 1860. By that year, he held a minor public office as a chancery court commissioner in Vicksburg, assisting in sales of property from court decisions. He also was appointed quartermaster general of the Mississippi militia at the rank of major. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Barbour volunteered for military service, and served in the Twenty-first Mississippi Infantry Regiment. In 1863, he received an appointment as Governor John J. Pettus’s private secretary in Jackson, and served in that role for several weeks.

Shortly after the war ended, Barbour partnered with J. W. Stratton to form a commission merchant and wholesale grocery business in Vicksburg. His fate after 1866 is not clear, as his business ventures no longer appeared in Mississippi, nor did he appear in any other state or local office.

(Vicksburg Whig, Vicksburg, MS, September 5, 1860; The Ripley Advertiser, Ripley, MS, January 18, 1860; Compiled Service Records of Confederate Soldiers Who Served in Organizations from the State of Mississippi, Record Group 109, Reference 1371.jp2, Series M269, Roll 293; “Legal. Document from Susan Ashley to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus; April 11, 1863,” Civil War and Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_757-944-10-18; The Vicksburg Herald, Vicksburg, MS, January 21, 1866)

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
Located in Hancock County, Bay Saint Louis was incorporated under the name Shieldsborough in 1818 and renamed Bay St. Louis in 1882. Bay Saint Louis serves as the county seat. (Britannica; Wikipedia)

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where criminals are kept as a punishment for their crimes or while waiting for trials." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p: On the 30" ^1861^ of April Victor Bogurt a prisoner from Hancock County Miss was sentenced to the Miss Penty—Judge Hancock presiding—Judge Hancock advised me by letter of his conviction and sentence—before I sent for him I recd information that he the prisoner had made his escape from the jail of Hancock County.—about the last of Sept of the same year he was rearrested and delivered to Capt Mc-Manis—of this place who was then at the Bay of St Lewis by the sheriff of Hancock County—requestg him to bring him to Jackson—Capt. McMannis did not receve any papers from the sheriff—The county cite being some 25 miles from the Bay of St Lewis.—Capt. McManis brought him over to New Orleans—and placed him for safe keeping in one of the city Lockups—The next morning the prison keeper refused to deliver him to Capt McManis—He therefore came home without him He communicated the facts to me—I at once repaired to the City of New Orleans—and having no requisition had some trouble to get him—They finally delivered him up—.—

I at once wrote to the Circuit Clerk of the County of Hancock for a copy of the sentence I afterwards wrote some two or three letters to the clerk for the same purpose.—I also telegraphed Judge Hancock a few days since to ascertain what he remembered about it—I have after proper diligence failed to get the necessary information as to the length of his sentence—
